A plane is at rest on an airport runway. The brakes of the plane are released and the engine of the plane provides a constant accelerating force
Using the following data, calculate the take-off speed of the plane. Ignore any resistive forces
constant forward force \(= 56000 \text{N}\)
mass of plane \(= 16000 \text{kg}\)
time of travel along runway \(= 16 \text{s}\)
Explain why momentum is a vector quantity
the change of momentum of the car,
change of momentum =   .........
the average force acting on the car
average force =   .........
The crumple zone at the front of a car is designed to collapse during a collision
In a laboratory test, a car of mass \(1200\mathrm{kg}\) is driven into a concrete wall, as shown in Fig. 2.1
A video recording of the test shows that the car is brought to rest in \(0.36\mathrm{s}\) when it collides with the wall. The speed of the car before the collision is \(7.5\mathrm{m / s}\)
Calculate
The energy absorbed by the crumple zone is \(4.3 \times 10^{5} \text{J}\). Show that the speed of the car before the collision is \(24 \text{m/s}\)
Suggest what would happen to the car if it is travelling faster than \(24 \text{m/s}\) when it hits the wall
A different car has a mass of \(1500\mathrm{kg}\). It collides with the same wall and all of the energy transferred during the collision is absorbed by the crumple zone
does not accelerate,
does not rotate
A stationary object is acted upon by a number of forces
State the conditions which **must** be true if the object
the moment of the weight of the boat about the point \(\mathbf{P}\),
the tension \(T_{1}\),
the tension \(T_{2}\)
Fig. 3.1 shows a boat that has been lifted out of a river. The boat is suspended by two ropes. It is stationary
The weight of the boat, acting at the centre of mass, is \(24 \text{kN}\). The tensions in the ropes are \(T_1\) and \(T_2\)
Determine
Explain, in terms of density, why bulb A is at the bottom of the cylinder and the other bulbs are floating
Suggest one reason why there is a delay before the temperature of the water increases to \(23^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
Explain why, after this delay, bulb B sinks. Assume the bulbs do not expand
The temperature of the surrounding air increases to a temperature above \(23^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
Bulbs A, B and C are now at the bottom of the cylinder. Bulbs D and E are floating
State the possible temperature range of the water in the cylinder
Fig. 4.1 shows a Galilean thermometer. This thermometer is used to measure the approximate temperature of the surrounding air
The glass cylinder contains water. When the temperature of the water changes, so does its density
Each bulb has a label printed with a temperature, as shown in Fig. 4.1. The bulbs have different densities. At \(21^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\), only bulb A is at the bottom of the cylinder
State two ways in which evaporation is different from boiling
Give one example of a change of state which does not involve boiling or evaporation
State what is taking place at points A, B and C. You should say what changes of state, if any, are taking place
point A
point B
point C
Suggest why the graph is steeper at point C than at point A
The graph in Fig. 5.1 shows the variation of temperature with time for a substance that is initially liquid
State the two types of radiation that are emitted by the heater
Before the heater is switched on, the liquid levels in the glass tube are the same
State and explain any changes in the liquid levels that take place when the heater is switched on
Fig. 6.1 shows apparatus that is used to demonstrate some effects of the transfer of energy by radiation
The glass bulb painted matt black, the shiny glass bulb and the spaces above the liquid in the tube all contain air
The heater glows red when switched on. The heater is the same distance from each bulb
Place a tick \((\checkmark)\) in all boxes that correctly describe the image

Use the ray you have drawn in **(b)** to determine the focal length of the lens
focal length =   .........
Draw another ray, **not** passing through a principal focus of the lens, that passes from the tip of the object to the tip of the image.
Fig. 7.1 shows an object and its image formed by a converging lens. One ray from the tip of the object to the tip of the image is shown

material
reason

material
reason
A transformer consists of two coils of wire wound on a core
State the difference between transformer X and transformer Y

from 0V to 1.0V,
from 1.0V to 8.0V

the resistance of the lamp,
resistance =   .........
the power of the lamp

the electromotive force (e.m.f.) of the power supply,
the current from the power supply

Fig. 10.1 shows a lightning flash between a cloud and the ground beneath

The charge built up on the cloud before the lightning flash is \(0.60 \text{C}\). This charge is completely transferred to the ground by the lightning flash in \(5.0 \times 10^{-5} \text{s}\) \((0.000050 \text{s})\)
State the evidence that each type of radiation is present in, or absent from, the radiation emitted by the source
\(\alpha\) -particles
\(\beta\)-particles
\(\gamma\)-rays
Determine how much of the original count rate of 150 counts/s, if any, is due to each type of radiation
-particles   .........  counts/s
-particles   .........  counts/s
-rays   .........  counts/s
A radioactive source is placed \(20\mathrm{mm}\) from a radiation detector, as shown in Fig. 11.1
The initial count rate recorded by the detector is 150 counts/s
A sheet of paper is placed between the source and the detector. The count rate recorded by the detector falls to 60 counts/s
With the paper still in place, a magnetic field is set up perpendicular to the direction of the radiation. The count rate recorded by the detector falls to 20 counts/s
The count rates have not been corrected for background. The background count is measured as 20 counts/s
